title.justification: This is the exact title of the paper.

extractions.description: This paper investigates the ability of diffusion models to perform vision-and-language reasoning tasks. It introduces a novel method called Diffusion Image-Text Matching (DiffusionITM) and a benchmark named GDBench to evaluate such models.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments and evaluations on various vision-and-language tasks to test the capabilities of diffusion models.
type.quote: In this work, we evaluate language-conditioned generative image models on discriminative tasks to shed light on their fine-grained understanding of vision and language.

name.justification: The study focuses on vision-and-language reasoning tasks and uses image-text matching benchmarks.
name.quote: We focus on image-text-matching (ITM) tasks due to their general applicability and simplicity.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses vision-and-language reasoning tasks using diffusion models.
name.quote: We hypothesize that a generative model trained to synthesize compositional data is capable of understanding the complexities required to solve hard image-text-matching tasks.

name.justification: The paper evaluates Stable Diffusion 1.5 in various vision-and-language tasks.
The paper evaluates Stable Diffusion 2.1 to compare its performance with version 1.5.
name.quote: We further boost its compositional performance with a transfer setup by fine-tuning on MS-COCO while retaining generative capabilities... Stable Diffusion 2.1 is less biased than 1.5.

name.justification: The paper uses CLIP as a baseline for comparison with Stable Diffusion.
name.quote: GDBench allows head-on comparison between generative models, as well as with discriminative models like CLIP [Radford et al., 2021].

name.justification: HardNeg-DiffusionITM is introduced in the paper as a fine-tuned version of DiffusionITM.
name.quote: Our goal is to transform diffusion-based models for discriminative image-text-matching (ITM)... The resulting model, HardNeg-DiffusionITM, is still evaluated in a zero-shot fashion on the target evaluation tasks.

name.justification: The paper evaluates models using the CLEVR dataset for compositionality tasks.
name.quote: Stable Diffusion + DiffusionITM is competitive on many tasks and outperforms CLIP on compositional tasks like CLEVR and Winoground.

name.justification: The paper uses DrawBench prompts for evaluating image-text alignment.
name.quote: We therefore compare image-text-alignment of DiffusionITM against HardNeg-DiffusionITM on DrawBench [Saharia et al., 2022] and find promising results.

name.justification: The paper mentions that the large pre-training corpus contains many noisy/simple examples.
name.quote: ...the denoising diffusion objective only considers positive image-text pairs, and the large pre-training corpus LAION [Schuhmann et al., 2021] contains many noisy/simple examples, not conductive to complex linguistic reasoning.

name.justification: The acknowledgment section states gratitude towards the open-source community behind Huggingface Diffusers library, indicating its use.
name.quote: We are grateful to the open-source community behind the Huggingface Diffusers library.
